results.title: The unsafe act
results.creator_credit: New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry, Fortune Films and R.D. Hansen
results.brief_description:
This 1965 film dramatises a number of industrial accidents and how to avoid them. The film shows footage of workers in various occupations such as window cleaning, welding and bricklaying, and shows accidents that can occur in these environments. The dramatic voiceover warns against haste, improvisation, carelessness and failure to use safety devices, emphasising that most accidents occur in this way.

Produced by Fortune Films for the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Safety in the slaughterhouse
results.creator_credit: Camfilm Productions, Peter Johnson and John Bowen
results.brief_description:
This 1979 film is directed at meat inspectors working in abbatoirs. The film contains footage of workers in abbatoirs and close-ups of inspectors working on carcasses. It includes interviews with three inspectors about the accidents they suffered during their work and a discussion at the pub between a group of meat inspectors on the problems they encounter in their work and the safety precautions they should note.

Produced by Camfilm Productions for the Department of Primary Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Safe loads
results.creator_credit: Pepper Audio Visual, South Australian Film Corporation, Peter Dimond and Max Pepper
results.brief_description:
This 1977 film demonstrates the importance of carrying a load safely on a truck. It details the necessary preparation for a drive, including the kind of load being carried, the stacking, placement and securing of the load. It includes a cameo appearance by American pro golfer Johnny Miller at the beginning, and a narrator speaking directly to the camera. Acknowledging that workers often find instructional videos condescending, the narrator speaks in a casual and familiar tone to appeal to the audience. He discusses the danger of petroleum and corrosive acids carried in tankers and the importance of stacking and securing a load correctly. The film ends with a dramatic re-enactment of experienced, yet careless, workers who secure a dangerous load onto a truck, which eventually explodes.

Produced for Mayne Nickless Limited by the South Australian Film Corporation and Pepper Audio Visual.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Johnny Miller, Roger Ward, Dave Taylor, Robyn Hamilton, Richard Pepper, Ian Gray, David Hursthouse

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Noise destroys
results.creator_credit: Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry, Tasmanian Film Corporation, John Honey and Phillip Mark-Law
results.brief_description:
This 1979 film deals with the effects of industrial noise on hearing. Presented as a dramatic short film, the narrative follows the protagonist, Len, as he discovers he is partially deaf due to twenty years of working with loud machines in a factory and goes on a crusade to improve working conditions. The film is directed at employers as well as employees, showing the importance of wearing safety gear and machines being modified or insulated to limit sound production. The film contains light-hearted moments of comedy, as Len goes about convincing his colleagues and management of the significance of the issue.

Produced by the Tasmanian Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Max Cullen, Brian Duhig, Barry Pierce, John Hale, Keith Jarvis, Barrie Muir, Jack Perry, Richard Meredith, Billie Hammerberg, Tony Boden, Kevin Lacey, Don Glover, Tracy Lee, Bob Gunning, Peter Lewis, Matthew Rhodes

results.title: It wasn't me
results.creator_credit: Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry, Tasmanian Film Corporation, John Honey and Eddie Moses
results.brief_description:
This 1978 film consists of a short narrative demonstrating the need for observing industrial safety standards on building sites. The film’s cast of characters includes a wealthy contractor, a negligent foreman, a disgruntled safety warden, a foreign labourer and a department inspector, as they attempt to reconstruct what happened to a missing worker following a trench collapse. Each of the characters avoids responsibility in their roles and blames the others for the accident. Presented as a dramatic short with points of comedy (though this is mainly through the slapstick representation of an Italian worker who doesn’t speak English), the film emphasises the importance of all members of the workforce taking responsibility for upholding safe practices on site.

Produced by the Tasmania Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Peter Aanensen, Frank Bansel, Brendan Cassidy, Cul Cullen, Cliff Ellen, Don Glover, Peter Kay, Kevin Lacey, Robert Larkins, Sue Ellen Peers, Robert Ward

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Explosives: the two metre lifeline
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, Milton Ingerson and Donald Crombie
results.brief_description:
In this 1974 film, the use of comedy and narrative drama are employed to demonstrate the correct handling of explosives and detonators. Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Mines Department, the film shows three people who handle explosives in the course of an ordinary day: a farmer removing tree stumps from his paddock, an opal miner in Coober Pedy and a ‘powder monkey’ on a road construction crew.

Introduced by a stereotypical ‘Aussie bloke’ drinking a beer at the pub, the film follows the three protagonists through their separate stories, as the narrator points out the mistakes and correct methods in their techniques. Demonstrating a casual, light-hearted approach to safety instruction, this film is a humorous presentation filled with expletives and colloquial terms, aimed to speak to workers on their level.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't Be Scalped
results.creator_credit: New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry, Fortune Film Productions and R.D. Hansen
results.brief_description:
In this 1960 film, we see female machine operators working in factories. The film focuses on a woman named Judy, describing her outfit and the dangers associated with wearing high-heeled shoes, full skirts, jewellery and long hair while operating a machine. The film then shows Judy dressed in the correct clothing options, including protective shoes, coveralls and cap to cover her hair. It also gives advice on how to lift heavy objects. As opposed to the safety films directed at male workers, the narrator focuses on physical appearance throughout the film, describing Judy as attractive, charming and pretty, and warning against fatigue, wear on clothing, disfigurement and scalping.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Think twice
results.creator_credit: Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia. Film Unit., James Levy, Keith Gow and Norma Disher
results.brief_description:
This 1958 film demonstrates the hazards associated with the boilermaking trade. It outlines the dangers of heat, infrared and ultraviolet rays and fumes, which are encountered with oxyacetylene and electric arc welding. It shows how accidents happen with each of these dangers and the types of injury suffered, including burns, eye injury and blindness, and serious illness caused by inhalation of fumes. It also shows how accidental explosions can occur when using welding equipment, and the importance of safe practices when welding, particularly in confined spaces.

The film emphasises the protective gear and equipment recommended at the time that should be used in order to avoid these hazards. It also shows teenage apprentices, some very young, being trained in safety practices. The film takes place at Cockatoo Docks and Engineering Company, a shipbuilding company that operated on Cockatoo Island, Sydney, between 1933 and 1992.

Produced by the Waterside Workers’ Federation of Australia Film Unit and presented by the Boilermakers’ Society of Australia and Protector Safety Products Pty. Ltd. Sydney, Australia.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: [Remix: Sunnies]
results.brief_description:
Worn at the beach or on a bush walk, or simply as a style statement, this playful short film is a tribute to the fashion accessory, and sun-smart, sun glasses. Set to a boss nova soundtrack, this short work is a tribute to ‘shades’, showing people wearing sun glasses cut from home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection. Featured are some of fashion’s best styles of eye wear from the 1940s to the 1970s.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office; Elenor Peach; Barry Parsons; The Gadsden Family and Neville Daley.

results.title: Waterfront safety
results.creator_credit: Western Australian Government Film Unit and Western Australia. Dept. of Labour
results.brief_description:
This 1966 film takes place on the wharfs and ships at Fremantle Harbour, demonstrating safe working methods for waterside workers. It shows the correct handling of various types of cargo, including logs, grain and phosphate mined from Nauru. It emphasises the use of protective clothing and equipment. The film also shows the prevention and control of fires, including fire fighting ships.

Produced by the Western Australian Government Film Unit and presented by the Western Australian Department of Labour with Accident Prevention Organisation (Shipping).

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.
